explanation:
CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE: the for-loop's second clause is `i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE`. You must see the macro/definition to ensure it is a pure compile-time constant or an expression without side effects or aliases to objects that might be modified in the loop body. If it expands to an expression with side effects or to an object that can be modified in the loop body the loop may violate MISRA.

CPU_ISSET: used inside the loop body. You must inspect its definition (macro or function) to ensure it does not modify the loop counter `i` or any other object used in the for-clause, and that it has no persistent side effects. MISRA requires that functions called from the loop body be considered part of the loop behaviour.

CPU_SETSIZE: CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE may be defined in terms of CPU_SETSIZE; include it so you can fully evaluate CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE and verify it is side‑effect free and not subject to modification in the loop body.

HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY and HAVE_CPU_COUNT: these preprocessor configuration symbols control whether the for-loop is present (the loop is inside #if defined(HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY) and only used when HAVE_CPU_COUNT is not defined). To determine whether the for-loop actually participates in the compiled function (and thus whether the MISRA check applies), the analyzer needs these build-time macros/definitions.
